text: Patient: Pat We’re looking at potent—very, uh, plausibly potential choices down the road. Doctor: Yes. Patient: And, and, and so at this point --- Doctor: I mean, including standard of care. So, standard of care is always our baseline. Patient: Right. Doctor: And then we, you know, I could just, my description will be, “here’s what standard of care does, here’s what we expect.” Patient: Well, well, I guess what I’m asking, if my PSA stays down - Doctor: The standard of care is – Patient: We should do nothing. Doctor: Is continue just doing what we’re doing. Patient: Eve—even, not even the clinical trial? Doctor: Right. One of the reasons for that has to do with, you know, how do we evaluate you on a clinical trial? What are our markers? PSA level?

text: Patient: Well I mean is there a benefit to taking the pain medication? Doctor: Yeah, you’d be more functional. Patient: Well I’m functionable. Family Member: But you’re in pain. Patient: Well then I also feel that if I’m masking the pain too much, then I’m overextending myself. Or maybe I shouldn’t be. Doctor: Oh well, set your activity level and don’t exceed it. Patient: Then I don’t need pain medication. Family Member: Yeah, but you can’t walk around in the stores; you can’t walk around for any length of time. If we go to Florida in February, you have to be able to walk on the beach; you aren’t going to be able to - Patient: But then again, if I’m taking pain medication to hide that pain, is that a good idea because then I’m gonna overextend myself. Doctor: I am so not going to get in the middle of this discussion with you two. You know the answer. If you need to go somewhere and be functional, go take your medication. You’re just chillaxing in front of the television, you’re probably just fine. Family Member: Right. Doctor: I’m sure you over-did it. I should have gone by your house and taken that darned ladder. I didn’t.

text: Family Member: Hormone therapy does? Doctor: Yeah, because it castrates you. It puts you into menopause. And we can talk some more about that. The um uh - another approach, so if we do that; let’s just focus on that, knowing that the cancer is down here in the pelvis, if you look at all the guys that get treated with radiation plus hormones and you look five years from now- Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: everybody’s alive, okay. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: Half the guys have their cancer come back, meaning they weren’t cured by the surgery, radiation and hormones. Half of the guys are cured by the hormones and radiation. You know it sort of mops up what’s left. Okay, so at minimum the standard of care is for you to do radiation plus hormones. I can tell you why they have the hormones. If they do the radiation alone, only thirty percent of the guys are cured five years from now. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: The good news is just so you hear it, is half the guys are cured at five years and then if you look ten years down – Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: - the line, nine out of ten guys are still alive if you go through the hormones and surgery, hormones and radiation, okay. Patient: Sure, uh hum. Doctor: You may be fighting prostate cancer, but you’re alive.

text: Patient: No. Doctor: No? Patient: No. Doctor: Then why did I bring you back? Patient: You said I have to change, huh, some treatment. Doctor: Let me see what I’ve got here. So you’ve got pain. Have you already seen these labs or everything I’m going to tell you is new? Patient: You going to tell me new. Doctor: Let me see what I have. You had your bloodwork yesterday. So your white count’s normal. Huh, you’re anemic, been about the same. You’ve got normal platelets. text: Healthcare Professional: Uh, yes. CALLER Good afternoon, Infusion, this is M_. Doctor: M_ in charge? CALLER Yes. Family Member: Umm, will the, will the chemo class help me understand what my, what I need to do to protect him from whatever I’m supposed to protect him from? Doctor: Uh, yes, I mean, they will allow you to ask questions about anything you should be worried about, things you’ve heard, and you can go from there as to sort of whether should you worry or not worry. Umm. And so these are people that have been through it with a lot of people, so they should be able to guide you about what, you know, what’s real worry and what’s not real worry. Family Member: So, we’re normally the household that people come to for Christmas, probably twenty five people. Depending on where we are in the scheme of things, do I want that many people around? Doctor: Uh, right. So, when you pick your date for chemo with T_, Family Member: Hm Hmm. Doctor: you can sorta plan it out. So, the week that’s the scariest is if you get your chemo and Christmas and all those people are there seven to ten days after, that’s dangerous. Healthcare Professional: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Okay, but, if it’s the twenty, you know the eighteenth day of the cycle… Patient: So, apply the no-fly rule. Doctor: ‘Cuz again if

text: Family Member: What do you mean a dip? Doctor: Meaning it destroys too much. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: And there’s no coming back. But you know in terms of how much does that occur, it’s very rare. Could it occur—sure, and I tend to see it in folks who have had a lot of therapy, especially chemo. You’ve had pills and more pills, a little smattering of radiation and a Provenge, and a partridge in a pear tree. So where you are coming in is your bone marrow is not as compromised as a person who had chemo. I’m not saying that you couldn’t get it after chemo, but the perfect person to give it in is a person who is actually having some pain, which you are, a person that otherwise is in good shape, and has a good enough bone marrow reserve, which you do, and it’s not related to any other treatment like steroids and things like that, where if I were to offer chemo, that would be part of the package. Again, not impossible for us to go down the chemo route, but that’s also the next discussion. But for this, I think it’s reasonable to talk to the radiation doctor about it because you’ll want to know pros and cons. So the bone marrow is the thing I always worry about, but for my other patients, and I’ve had many go through it, the other part that it could affect would be your gut. So diarrhea, stomach upset, not so much nausea and vomiting but just more like you know you’ve got the poops kind of thing. But for you it’s obviously something we could regulate because you could get Imodium, you know. You could get treatment. A lot of my patients have it during the time around you know the week that you get injected and then nothing else. So that’s kind of where it is. Oh, and if you have cancer that’s not in the bone, like liver or lungs, which you don’t have, but those patients, they don’t; you know they shouldn’t be treated with this medicine because that medicine that I’m thinking about for you is only for bone. So it will not go to liver or anywhere else. Family Member: So the pain that he’s having - Doctor: Is in bone. Family Member: And how big of a spot does he have there – on his hip and lower leg, upper leg. Doctor: Yeah, I mean it’s not a humongous spot. But it still is enough for it’s - Family Member: Causing pain. Doctor: Uh hum. Family Member: I thought maybe he might have hurt his self when he was carrying boxes up and down stairs Doctor: No, now we’re down now, though, right? No more. Patient: Well, I don’t think it was so much carrying boxes because my kids and my wife wouldn’t let me carry weight.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
